metadata.case_name: Appellant (successors of Shah Manilal Maganlal) v. Respondents (plaintiff firm)

facts.text: Bhankoda estate in Viramgam taluka, Ahmedabad district, jointly owned by several talukdars, comprises twelve villages including Rampura where suit lands (survey Nos. 222, 223, 225, 226) are situate.
By Government Resolution No. 8170 dated 30th August 1912, the estate was taken under Government management under section 28 of the Gujarat Talukdars Act (Bombay Act VI of 1888).
Shah Manilal Maganlal and Bros. (predecessors in interest of appellant) desired to erect ginning factory on survey Nos. 222, 225, 226 and approached Talukdari Settlement Officer for permanent lease.
Talukdari Settlement Officer agreed to grant lease subject to Government sanction.
On 9th December 1916, Shah Manilal Maganlal made written application to Talukdari Settlement Officer offering permanent lease of survey numbers at annual rental of Rs. 290 for ginning factory.

On 12th July 1917, Talukdari Settlement Officer provisionally accepted offer after considering talukdars' objections and permitted entry on land in anticipation of Government sanction under section 27A Court of Wards Act (applicable via section 29G Gujarat Talukdars Act).
Papers submitted to Government; conditions of lease annexed.
On 20th July 1917, Commissioner forwarded papers to Government with recommendations.
By Resolution No. 10795 dated 5th September 1917, Government sanctioned the arrangement (Exhibit 181 is certified copy of Chief Secretary's letter detailing steps).
Binding agreement to lease effected between Talukdari Settlement Officer and Shah Manilal Maganlal with Government sanction; draft formal deed prepared but not executed/registered.
Lessee took possession soon after, erected ginning/pressing factory, bungalow, engine rooms; tendered and paid agreed rent Rs. 290 annually to Talukdari Settlement Officer for about two years.
Estate released from Government management; manager appointed by talukdars continued receiving rent as settled.
On 4th May 1924, Shah Manilal Maganlal effected possessory mortgage of ginning factory and buildings for Rs. 1,40,000 in favour of defendant (appellant).
Contestants (defendant and plaintiffs) acquired rights in 1924-25: defendant as mortgagee, plaintiffs as ijaradar and assignee of mortgage rights; plaintiffs received rent per grant.
In 1933, appellant purchased equity of redemption at court auction, vested with rights of Manilal Maganlal; property value ~Rs. 38,000.
Plaintiffs (respondents) filed suit No. 830/1933 in July 1933 for ejectment of survey Nos. 222,223,225,226 and mesne profits, alleging no registered lease, trespassers.

Plaint paras 2-3 admit correspondence negotiated 50-year lease at Rs. 290 but no formal registered lease; para 4 challenges Settlement Officer's authority; para 8 admits rent received to 31st July 1932, notice given 25th Dec 1930 unnecessary as trespasser.
Defendant pleaded permanent tenancy, estoppel by conduct, plaintiffs no right to sue.
Joint Sub-Judge decreed suit: no written lease, no equitable part performance.
Review dismissed on fresh materials ground.
Appeal No. 173/1936 to Assistant Judge: ground 3 on S.53A TPA; remand order 30th July 1938 under O.XLI R.25 on issues: mortgagee in occupation? Non-joinder?
Trial Judge post-remand reported against plaintiffs, admitted Ex.181 etc.; Assistant Judge on 27th April 1940 allowed appeal, dismissed suit applying S.53A TPA.

High Court Second Appeal No.717/1940 dated 9th March 1943 allowed plaintiffs' appeal: decreed ejectment for 223,225; dismissed for 222,226; held plaintiffs entitled to sue, no S.53A as no signed contract evident from correspondence.
Plaintiff witness admitted reading correspondence recited in plaint para 2; originals not produced despite notice, in possession of plaintiffs/talukdars.

legal_issues.text: Whether the plaintiff firm has proved its title to maintain the suit in ejectment against the defendant.
Whether the defendant is entitled to the benefit of section 53-A of the Transfer of Property Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: No registered lease; defendant trespasser; no authority of Talukdari Settlement Officer; rent received but no notice needed; challenged S.53A applicability as no signed writing evidencing contract with ascertainable terms.
Correspondence summarized in Ex.181 not evidence of contract; terms not ascertainable with certainty.

respondent_arguments.text: Permanent tenant via written agreement sanctioned by Government; plaintiffs estopped; S.53A applies as written signed contract, part performance by possession, buildings, rent payment.
Plaintiffs no complete title, no right to sue.

court_reasoning.text: Plaintiffs entitled to sue as ijaradar/assignee or by defendant's admission via rent payment treating as landlord; alternatively Ginwalla as receiver.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Defendant paid rent for full shares, cannot dispute right to sue.

court_reasoning.text: S.53A applies: Ex.181 reliable secondary evidence of signed written offer/acceptance/sanction; terms (permanent lease, Rs.290 rent, revise after 50 years) ascertainable; possession taken in part performance, buildings erected, rent paid continuously; willing to perform (execute lease).
court_reasoning.key_observation: No formal lease needed; agreement via writings binding; originals withheld justifies secondary evidence.

court_reasoning.text: High Court erred in holding Ex.181 not evidence of contract; possession post-sanction, not anticipatory.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Equity of part performance supports defence; S.53A bars ejectment.

holdings.text: Defendant entitled to protection under section 53-A of Transfer of Property Act as conditions satisfied via written agreement evidenced by Ex.181, part performance.
Plaintiffs have title to sue, but barred from ejectment by S.53A.

statutes_cited.name: Gujarat Talukdars Act (Bombay Act VI of 1888)
statutes_cited.relevance: Government management of estate; applicability of Court of Wards Act

statutes_cited.name: Transfer of Property Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Defence of part performance barring ejectment despite unregistered contract

statutes_cited.name: Specific Relief Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Equity of part performance for leases supports independent action (post-1930, not applicable here)

statutes_cited.name: Indian Registration Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Unregistered lease agreement admissible as evidence of part performance

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside High Court decree, restored Assistant Judge's decree dismissing the suit, holding S.53A TPA bars ejectment.

key_quotes.text: "Ex. 181 shows that the terms of the lease have been reduced to writing though no regular lease appears to have been executed. ... section 53-A of the Transfer of Property Act is a complete answer."
key_quotes.speaker: lower_court
key_quotes.significance: Assistant Judge's application of S.53A upheld by SC

key_quotes.text: "The section is a partial importation in the statute law of India of the English doctrine of part-performance."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "We are therefore of the opinion that the learned Assistant Judge rightly dismissed the plaintiffs suit and the High Court was in error in interfering with that decision in second appeal."
key_quotes.speaker: court
